trustfund: TF023141-CANADA-SDA IN SSA II,TF032263-SIERRA LEONE - MACROECONOMICS

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Public Sector
            Management Support Project is rated as unsatisfactory,
            sustainability as unlikely, institutional development impact
            as modest, Bank performance as unsatisfactory, and Borrower
            performance as unsatisfactory. The economic situation and
            political instability from 1993 to 1997 affected the
            implementation of the project. The key lessons learned from
            this project are: The project design should be simple. The
            components should reflect only the highest priorities of the
            Government and not lump together all desirable public sector
            issues to be resolved in one project in a country where
            implementation capacity is weak. There is a need for a
            review and revision of project design midstream by taking
            into consideration external circumstances. In a very weak
            institutional setting, it is important to limit the number
            of studies in a project because of inadequate capacity to
            implement the studies. It is also important to provide
            support to building capacity of local training institutions
            for the continuous training of the public service. In a
            post-conflict situation, the benefits can be large from not
            closing down completely a project that is supporting reform
            in public sector institutions, but leaving some modest
            amount of funds available to enable some state institutions
            to perform basic and vital functions in critical areas in
            order to minimize state failure.
